para.p:
We call
Φ
a phase and
ψ
an amplitude, and
⁢ I
( λ )
an oscillatory integral.
The following proof follows Stein and Shakarchi. 1 1 footnote 1 Elias M. Stein and Rami Shakarchi, Functional Analysis, p. 325, Proposition 2.1.

If there is some
> c 0
such that
≥
|
⁢
(
∇ Φ
)
( x )
|
c
for all
∈ x
⁢ supp ψ

N

≥
c N
0
such that

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(I * lambda) less= c _ N * lambda ^ (- N), lambda > 0)

. 2 2 footnote 2 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 162, Theorem 6.20. Define

Math.text: L * f = (1 / (i * lambda)) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ d)@(a _ k * (partial-differential _ k)@(f)) = (1 / (i * lambda)) * (a cdot nabla) * f

para.p:
L
satisfies, doing integration by parts and using the fact that
a
has compact support,

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ d))@(L * f * g * differential-d@(x)) = (1 / (i * lambda)) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ d)@((integral _ (R ^ d))@(a _ k * (partial-differential _ k)@(f) * g * differential-d@(x))) = (1 / (i * lambda)) * (sum _ (k = 1)) ^ d - (integral _ (R ^ d))@(f * ((partial-differential _ k)@(g * a))@(d * x))

para.p:
Thus the transpose of
L
is

Math.text: L ^ t * g = - (1 / (i * lambda)) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ d)@((partial-differential _ k)@(g * a)) = - ((1 / (i * lambda)) * nabla) cdot (g * a)

para.p:
Furthermore, in
⁢ supp ψ
,

Math.text: L * e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) = e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ d)@(a _ k * (partial-differential _ k)@(Phi)) = e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ d)@(((partial-differential _ k)@(Phi) / (absolute-value@(nabla@(Phi))) ^ 2) * (partial-differential _ k)@(Phi)) = e ^ (i * lambda * Phi)
L * e ^ (i * lambda * Phi)
e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ d)@(a _ k * (partial-differential _ k)@(Phi))
e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ d)@(((partial-differential _ k)@(Phi) / (absolute-value@(nabla@(Phi))) ^ 2) * (partial-differential _ k)@(Phi))
e ^ (i * lambda * Phi)

para.p:

N
and for

para.p: But

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ d))@(absolute-value@(L ^ t ^ N * psi) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(absolute-value@(lambda ^ (- N) * A _ N) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: completing the proof. ∎
The following is an estimate for a one-dimensional oscillatory integral without an amplitude term. 3 3 footnote 3 Elias M. Stein and Rami Shakarchi, Functional Analysis, p. 326, Proposition 2.2.

para.p: Write

Math.text: L = (1 / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime)) * (d / (d * x))

para.p: which satisfies

Math.text: ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(L * f * g * differential-d@(x)) = ((integral _ a) ^ b)@((1 / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime)) * f ^ prime * g * differential-d@(x)) = evaluated-at@((1 / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime)) * f * g, a, b) - ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(f * (g / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime)) ^ prime * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
With
= f

((integral _ a) ^ b)@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * differential-d@(x))
evaluated-at@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime), a, b) - ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * (1 / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime)) ^ prime * differential-d@(x))
evaluated-at@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime), a, b) + (1 / (i * lambda)) * ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * Phi ^ prime ^ (- 2) * Phi ^ prime2 * differential-d@(x))

Math.text: absolute-value@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi * b) / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime * b) - e ^ (i * lambda * Phi * a) / (i * lambda * Phi ^ prime * a)) less= 1 / (lambda * absolute-value@(Phi ^ prime * b)) + 1 / (lambda * absolute-value@(Phi ^ prime * a)) less= 2 / lambda

para.p:

or

(1 / lambda) * absolute-value@(((integral _ a) ^ b)@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * Phi ^ prime ^ (- 2) * Phi ^ prime2 * differential-d@(x)))
(1 / lambda) * ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(absolute-value@(Phi ^ prime ^ (- 2) * Phi ^ prime2) * differential-d@(x))
(1 / lambda) * absolute-value@(((integral _ a) ^ b)@(Phi ^ prime ^ (- 2) * Phi ^ prime2 * differential-d@(x)))
(1 / lambda) * absolute-value@(1 / (Phi ^ prime * a) - 1 / (Phi ^ prime * b))
1 / lambda

para.p:
the final inequality uses the fact that the two terms inside the absolute value are both
≥
1
, and thus the absolute value can be bounded by the larger of them. Putting together the two inequalities,

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(((integral _ a) ^ b)@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi) * differential-d@(x))) less= 2 / lambda + 3 / lambda = 3 * lambda ^ (- 1), lambda > 0)

For
∈ n Z
, the
n
th Bessel function of the first kind
:
J n
→ R R
is

Math.text: formulae@(J _ n * lambda = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (i * lambda * sine@(x)) * e ^ (- i * n * x) * differential-d@(x)), lambda element-of R)

para.p: Let

Math.text: formulae@(I _ 1 = closed-interval@(0, pi / 4), formulae@(I _ 2 = closed-interval@((3 * pi) / 4, pi), formulae@(I _ 3 = closed-interval@(pi, (5 * pi) / 4), I _ 4 = closed-interval@((7 * pi) / 4, 2 * pi))))

Math.text: absolute-value@((integral _ I _ k)@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi * x) * psi * x * differential-d@(x))) less= c _ psi * mu ^ (- 1) * lambda ^ (- 1) = (3 * (1 + (pi * n) / 4)) cdot square-root@(2) cdot lambda ^ (- 1)

para.p:

Math.text: absolute-value@((integral _ I _ k)@(e ^ (i * lambda * Phi * x) * psi * x * differential-d@(x))) less= c _ psi * mu ^ (- 1 / 2) * lambda ^ (- 1 / 2) = (8 * (1 + (pi * n) / 2)) cdot 2 ^ (1 / 4) cdot lambda ^ (- 1 / 2)

para.p: Therefore

Math.text: absolute-value@(J _ n * lambda) less= ((4 cdot (1 / (2 * pi)) cdot 3) * (1 + (pi * n) / 4)) cdot square-root@(2) cdot lambda ^ (- 1) + ((2 cdot (1 / (2 * pi)) cdot 8) * (1 + (pi * n) / 2)) cdot 2 ^ (1 / 4) cdot lambda ^ (- 1 / 2)

para.p:
which shows that for each
∈ n Z
,

Math.text: J _ n * lambda = O _ n * lambda ^ (- 1 / 2)
